subject: Some Love For Longclaw
event: After all the complaints and problems with the calendar, let me take this opportunity to point out that most of the other licensed Ice & Fire products are going just fine, thank you. Longclaw, for instance, the full-size replica of Jon Snow's bastard sword, is drawing some rave reviews, and my readers and fans have had nothing but good things to say about the professionalism and customer service of Chris Beasley and his crew at Valyrian Steel. Check out some of the comments for yourself at: http://www.valyriansteel.com/shop/swords/longclaw-sword-of-jon-snow/prod_2.html Remember, Valentine's Day is coming up soon. And nothing says love like Valyrian steel...

comments.article:
Nothing say love like Valyrian Steel.
hahaha
"honey.. is this... **clears throat** a F***ing sword?"
"not just any sword, its Longc...*SMACK

now on the other side of the coin
ME WANT!!
comments.subject: thats hilarious

comments.article: See, that just shows you're dating the wrong people. I would be ECSTATIC if Josh got me one of those.
comments.subject: Re: thats hilarious

comments.upictitle: pinikir: Rock Paper Scissors Lizard Spock
comments.article: *drools* I love the detail on it

"And nothing says love like Valyrian steel..."

That is the sexiest thing I've heard (er... read) all week!
I too am very much looking forward to Needle, something about that sword draws to me personally, maybe because Arya is my favorite character... that and Tyrion! Don't ask me why!
Is long claw battle ready or replica forged?
comments.subject: Sword Question

comments.article:
It's a replica. Valyrian Steel may made battle ready swords if there's sufficient demand, but they would cost three times as much.

Swords were never cheap, not even in the middle ages. Spears were the weapon of the commoners. Swords were for nobles.
comments.subject: Re: Sword Question

comments.article:
And nothing says love like Valyrian steel...

I wish... I don't think I'm allowed to have stabby pretties like that here in the UK. At least, that was the impression I was given before I immigrated here, as I ended up having to give my armory to a friend. :(

I am not from the UK myself, so I'm no expert, but I do have several friends over there who are into reenactments, and some of them have considerable armories.

One of them told me once that he was required to come down to the local police station and register his longsword. So it may be that you're allowed to own swords, but have to register them.

I do believe sword canes are illegal. Or so I was told when I tried to buy one once at a Longdon show whose large antique exteriors sign said "SWORD CANES."

(You can get some lovely sword canes in New Orleans, however).
comments.subject: swords in the UK

comments.article:
"Remember, Valentine's Day is coming up soon. And nothing says love like Valyrian steel..."

I have a new signature at the ASoIaF board...
Hm. "Valentine's Day is coming" just doesn't have the same cachet as "Winter is coming" ;-)

You can get sword canes in New Orleans? Huh, I thought they were illegal. I guess I'll need to go down there and get one, pretend to be Mr. Jeffers...

On the subject of Longclaw though, wow. I know what I'm saving my money for now.

is that sword seppuku suited?
if yes ,with which side?

I love the Longclaw I got for Christmas. It's a beautiful blade, hanging up in my office next to my window and computer. I can't wait to show it to friends.

The Valyrian steel folding look is a particularly nice touch and the blade as a whole feels really good in one's hands.

"And nothing says love like Valyrian steel..."

My wife showed me the sword and I said that would be pretty cool to have. Then walked away thinking nothing more of it. A bit later she walks in and says to me "Happy Valentines day" She ordered me the sword. Wow! I was shocked. It's going to look pretty cool up on my wall once it arrives. Thanks George.

comments.upictitle: J.A.C.K. Inc.  Super Secret Ninja Force: chiburi
comments.article:
As a sword collector, fencer, and practitioner of Iaido, that is a beautiful weapon. Like a fine shinken, the grain in the steel is magnificent.

Utsukushii desu ne! (beautiful)

I am still a bit baffled as to why isn't the sword sold out. I thought that the first week of pre-order will also be the last...as to the sword itself, it's a rare beauty in the replica world, the "Valyrian Steel" looks awesome but I have yet to see pictures that will make justice to the beauty of the steel.

Sold Out?
Please let's hope that they don't for the sake of those of us trying to save up for it!

Between the Sword, the Miniatures, the Calendar, the mini-busts, Mr Martin's book sales here and those amazing Illustrated Novels that he links to, then as an obsessive collect...uh, I mean enthusiastic supporter of Mr Martin's works ;) then I have to say that it's a struggle to keep up.

I would almost be tempted to believe that Mr Martin might take a bit of joy in his fans' suffering, though I'm sure that that could never be the case. *coughTheStarkscough*

In any event, I hope that the manufacturer continues to make them or perhaps might at least make a few extras for those of us who need a bit more time before being able to make the purchase. =)

I'd love this, but with the cost of postage to Australia being more than the cost of the sword I think I'll have to wait for Needle and be content with that.

Unless some other Australian fans have found a cheaper way of getting it here?
I want it so much but they don't ship to Japan. I shall just stare at the pretty pictures for now.
Must.. have.. sword! Too bad I'm just a paperboy! Wish I had some money to buy a nice, lovely valyrian steel sword.

Nothing is sweeter than the kiss of Valyrian steel on Valentine's Day.

Er, maybe not. :)

Chris Beasley of Valyrian Steel has been following some of the discussions here about the legality of swords in the UK, and has asked me to post the following:

"We've had no problem shipping any sword to the UK in the past. The only problem we've ever had was on smaller blades, less than 30 inches, that are sharpened on both sides (ie, a dagger, not a knife). I believe since it is smaller they consider the blade able to be concealed and so it doesn't get through, which isn't to mean it never gets through, sometimes they do, sometimes they don't, but the ones over 30 inches ALWAYS get through. For Australia it is the same way consequently. "

I hope this helps.

Keep your swords sharp! Or not, if that's da law.
comments.subject: blades in the UK

comments.article:
Well, I'm from Ireland, and I had no problems importing Longclaw. Going by the comments of my fellow sword-purchasers, it's the same across Europe. If you're in Europe, though, remember that, as with pretty much anything from the US, you'll have to pay Custom duties when it arrives. It's been the same for us all. Other than that, delivery is quite prompt. Hopefully Needle's sharpened carbon-steel won't cause issue when they are finished

Nice to have George's signature too! It'll tide me over until I see him at Octocon 2010! :D
comments.subject: Re: blades in the UK

comments.article: Any chance there might be a replica of King Stannis's sword Lightbringer made?  I just finished "A Storm of Swords" and was thoroughly impressed with the description given when Maester Aemon asks to see the sword.
comments.subject: Lightbringer?

comments.article:
Well, Mr. Martin, let me say that My (now) Wife got me Valyrian Steel's 'Needle' as a wedding gift, which now has pride of place on our wall.

So when you say:
Remember... nothing says love like Valyrian steel...

...I couldn't agree more :)
comments.subject: a perfect wedding gift....
